text.text_translated:
We buy many things in our lives. We own these things. But we can see this easily: we do not use all of them.
For example, we buy a thick woollen coat. We think it looks good. But we live in a tropical country. It is too hot to wear this coat.
We buy a smartphone. Then we buy a new model. We put the old smartphone away.
We have a car. We only use this car on weekends.
We have a guest room in our house. It changed into a storeroom by accident.

feedback.feedback: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6926 is too low, falling below the required 0.75. The original text conveys a nuanced idea of items being purchased but 'not being put to good use' or being underutilized, implying a degree of waste or inefficiency. The writer's output simplifies this to 'we do not use all of them', which loses the specific meaning of 'good use' or the implied regret/observation about underutilization. The core message about the *quality* or *sufficiency* of use is diminished. Suggestion: Rephrase the introductory sentences to more accurately reflect the concept of items being bought but not used effectively or sufficiently, rather than just stating they are not used.

best_attempt.text_translated:
Think about the things we buy.
We buy many things in our lives.
But not all things we own are used well.
For example, we buy a thick woollen coat.
We thought it looked trendy.
But we live in a tropical country.
We do not use the coat.
We also buy a smartphone.
Then we buy the newest model.
We put the old phone away.
We have a car.
We only use the car on weekends.
We have a guest room in our house.
It turned into a storeroom.
